**Crime and Punishment**

He remembered her pale and thin face, but those thoughts didn’t bother him now. He felt he would repay all her pain with great love. The struggles of the past, including his crime, punishment, and time in prison, seemed distant and unimportant to him now. That evening, he couldn't focus on anything for long; he was just feeling emotions. Life was taking over his thoughts, and something new was beginning to form in his mind.

Under his pillow was the New Testament. He picked it up without thinking. It belonged to Sonia; it was the book she read to him about Lazarus. At first, he worried she might talk to him about religion and push her beliefs on him. But to his surprise, she never brought it up and didn’t even offer him the book. He had asked her for it before he got sick, and she had given it to him quietly. He hadn’t opened it until now.

He didn’t open it now either, but one thought crossed his mind: "Could her beliefs be mine now? Her feelings and hopes…?"

She had been very upset that day, and at night she got sick again. But she was so happy—so unexpectedly happy—that it scared her a little. Seven years, just seven years! At the start of their happiness, they both felt ready to…

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist experiences a profound emotional transformation, feeling an overwhelming love and connection to Sonia, which overshadows his past suffering and crime.
